(b31yp/6-31+g(3df, 2p)) NOHSO4 −829.6060 ON −129.9084 HO3SO −699.6456 ONO −205.1045 HO3S −624.6456 E(N–O) 0.0520 E(O–S) 0.0595 Preparation of mesoporous SiO2–Al2O3 supported Co or Mn catalysts and their catalytic properties in cyclohexane nitrosation to ɛ-caprolactam Fang Hao a Jun Zhong a Ping-Le Liu a ⁎ Kui-Yi You a Chao Wei b Hua-Jie Liu c He-An Luo a ⁎ a College of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, China b College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Changsha University of Science & Technology, Changsha 410004, China c College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan Institute of Engineering, Xiangtan 411104, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 73158293545; fax: +86 73158298267. Graphical abstract Mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 and its supported Co or Mn catalysts were prepared and characterized. The catalytic properties of these catalysts in cyclohexane nitrosation to ɛ-caprolactam were investigated and a possible mechanism for liquid phase nitrosation of cyclohexane was proposed. Highlights ► One-pot synthesis of ɛ-caprolactam catalyzed by mesoporous crystalline Mn/SiO2–Al2O3. ► Brønsted acid caused by metal oxide species is helpful to cyclohexane nitrosation. ► Metals’ load decreases the activity while increases the selectivity to ɛ-caprolactam. ► A possible mechanism for liquid phase nitrosation of cyclohexane is proposed. Mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis method and its supported Co or Mn catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. These prepared materials were characterized by XRD, XPS, NH3–TPD, BET, FT-IR and TG–DSC. It reveals that the metals are substituted into the framework as the form of MnCo2O4, Mn3O4, MnO, Co3O4 and stronger acid sites appear. Furthermore, Pyridine FT-IR spectra and NH3–TPD results indicate that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites exist on these SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts and Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 exhibits higher Brønsted acid content. BET results show that SiO2–Al2O3 with middle Si/Al molar ratio has larger surface area and pore volume. The surface area and pore volume of SiO2–Al2O3 decrease after the introduction of the transition metals. The catalytic properties in the cyclohexane nitrosation to ɛ-caprolactam were performed and Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 exhibits better activity and selectivity to the ɛ-caprolactam. Keywords Mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 Supported transition metal catalysts ɛ-Caprolactam Cyclohexane Nitrosation 1 Introduction ɛ-Caprolactam is an important precursor for the manufacture of nylon-6 and plastics. The ever-increasing industrial demand for nylon-6 necessitates the development of environmentally benign method for the production of ɛ-caprolactam [1]. The commercial production of ɛ-caprolactam is still based on classical technologies. Cyclohexanone oxime is synthesized from cyclohexanone and hydroxylamine sulfate in the presence of ammonia. Then the Beckmann rearrangement in fuming sulfuric acid is carried out, and neutralization is followed to liberate the lactam [2,3]. The shortcomings of this classical process are its complex routes and a large amount of ammonium sulfate formed as by-product [2–4]. One of the improvements for the production of ɛ-caprolactam was direct ammoximation of cyclohexanone with ammonia and hydrogen peroxide catalyzed by TS-1 [5–7]. Researchers have studied Beckmann rearrangements in vapor phase using solid catalysts such as metal oxides and zeolites [8–13]. Liquid-phase Beckmann rearrangements using solid acid catalysts and zeolites have been carried out [14,15]. A few examples of solvent-free organo-catalyzed Beckmann rearrangements have been reported [16], as well as in supercritical water [17]. The research group of Cambridge University developed a process for the production of ɛ-caprolactam from cyclohexanone by using bifunctional heterogeneous nanoporous aluminophosphates catalysts containing isolate acidic and redox sites [18,19]. It can be seen that it is very attractive to replace those former mentioned complex routes with a new simple process. Naylor and Anderson developed a process for the synthesis of cyclohexanone oxime by cyclohexane photoreaction with nitrosyl chloride [20]. Compared with the classical routes, this photochemical process is simpler and the overall selectivity to ɛ-caprolactam is higher. However, it is of high energy consumption and the formation of NOCl is very problematic and environmentally unfriendly. Up to now, only Japan Toray Ltd. has this PNC (Photonitrosation of cyclohexane) commercial process [21]. Therefore, the development of a new catalytic system for replacing the photochemical process is highly desirable. ɛ-Caprolactam can be prepared in a single-step from cyclohexane and nitrosyl sulfuric acid in the presence of fuming sulfuric acid catalyzed by a series of transition metal supported on AlVPO composite or amorphous SiO2–Al2O3 prepared by sol–gel method [22–25]. It provides a novel strategy for one-step synthesis of ɛ-caprolactam from cyclohexane. The metal-containing mesoporous zeolites have attracted great interests as catalysts due to their acidity, redox, shape-selectivity and recyclable properties [26,27]. In this paper, we aim to search for suitable catalysts and studied their catalytic properties in the cyclohexane nitrosation to ɛ-caprolactam. Several types of mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts were prepared and characterized in this work. We found that these catalysts could efficiently catalyze the reaction of cyclohexane with nitrosyl sulfuric acid to afford ɛ-caprolactam via one-step in the presence of fuming sulfuric acid. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation SiO2–Al2O3 were prepared from Al(OH)3 and tetraethyl orthosilicate by hydrothermal synthesis method, and triethylamine was used as template. The Al(OH)3 was added into the water and then the tetraethyl orthosilicate was added after stirring 2h. Afterwards, the template was introduced dropwise under vigorous stirring. The gel was stirred for 2h before being sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, then it was heated to 120°C under autogeneous pressure for 12h. Finally, the gel was separated by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at 110°C for 12h. The obtained SiO2–Al2O3 was used as catalyst support. The SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. The metal precursor of cobalt acetate or manganese acetate was firstly dissolved in the deionized water to obtain a solution of 0.4mol/l, then the previous obtained SiO2–Al2O3 was impregnated in cobalt acetate or manganese acetate solution under stirring. After 2h, the mixture was filtrated and dried at 110°C for 12h. Finally, the obtained solid was calcinated at 600°C for 6h in air at a heating rate of 2°Cmin−1. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Japan Rigaku D/Max 2550 VB+ 18kW X-ray diffractometer under the following conditions: 40kV, 30mA, Cu Kα radiation, with a scanning rate of 1°min−1 in the range of 2θ =3–70°. The surface composition and surface electronic state were analyzed by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) using Kratos Axis Ultra DLD instrument at 160eV pass energy. Al Kα radiation was used to excited photoelectrons. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3 was carried out on a CHEMBET-3000 instrument. The samples were pretreated at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 to 650°C and was held for 30min under a flow of helium. After cooling to 100°C, a mixture of 10% NH3 to 90% He was introduced until the acid sites of the catalyst were saturated with NH3. Finally, desorption was carried out from 10°C to 650°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 380 spectrometer. The spectra of the samples were acquired in the wavenumber range of 400–4500cm−1. Pyridine FT-IR was used to distinguish the nature of the acid sites. Specific surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution of the samples were determined by N2 adsorption–desorption on a NOVA-2200e automated gas sorption system. Thermogravimetric (TG) and Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) analysis were recorded on Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1 with a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1 from 20°C to 800°C under 40mlmin−1 nitrogen. 2.3 Catalytic reaction Cyclohexane nitrosation was carried out in a 100ml glass reactor. Typically, 10g cyclohexane, 0.5g catalyst, 8g nitrosyl sulfuric acid and 24g 50wt.% fuming sulfuric acid were added into the reactor. Then it was heated to 81°C under stirring and reacted under this temperature for 24h. After reaction the unreacted cyclohexane was removed by rotary evaporator. The remained liquid was dissolved by deionized water in ice-water bath and treated with Ba(OH)2 to neutralize H2SO4. The reaction products were analyzed on a LC-20AT and SPD-20A liquid chromatograph with 20:80 of CH3OH:H2O as eluant and detected at wavelength of 210nm. The conversion and the selectivity were calculated using the following formulas (Eqs (1) and (2)). (1) Conversion ( % ) = [ the amount ( mol ) of starting cyclohexane − the amount ( mol ) of cyclohexane recovered ] the amount ( mol ) of nitrosyl sulfuric acid × 100 % (2) Selectivity ( % ) = the amount ( mol ) of caprolactam [ the amount ( mol ) of starting cyclohexane − the amount ( mol ) of cyclohexane recovered ] × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the SiO2–Al2O3 and the SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts. The XRD patterns of all the samples have the tridymite crystal structures, which is different from amorphous SiO2–Al2O3 prepared by sol–gel method in the work of Liu et al. [25]. The XRD patterns of SiO2 are in the region of 20.4–35.5° and the XRD peaks detected around 2θ =45.8° and 66.9° are attributed to γ-Al2O3. Besides the XRD peaks corresponding to the SiO2–Al2O3, the XRD patterns of Co–Mn/SiO2–Al2O3, Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 and Co/SiO2–Al2O3 catalysts exhibit the presence of additional XRD features. The peaks of 35.9°, 43.6° and 63.6° in curve b are attributed to MnCo2O4, which is formed when Co and Mn are introduced into the SiO2–Al2O3 synchronously. The peaks of 32.3° and 38.3° in curve Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 belong to Mn3O4 and MnO, respectively [28]. And the peaks of 36.6° and 59.3° in curve d are attributed to Co3O4, which are in good agreement with that reported by Yu et al. [29]. The XPS spectra of the SiO2–Al2O3 and the SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . Besides the characterization peaks corresponding to the atoms of the SiO2–Al2O3, the XPS spectra of Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 and Co/SiO2–Al2O3 exhibit the presence of the introduced metal atoms. The 640–770eV binding energy region includes the Mn 2s, Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 core levels [30] and the manganese content is 1.23at%. The characterization peaks between 779 and 928eV includes the Co 2p1/2, Co 2p3/2 and Co 2s [30] and the cobalt content is 1.07at%. As shown in Fig. 3 , the O 1s spectra of SiO2–Al2O3, Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 and Co/SiO2–Al2O3 are composed of two peaks and the binding energies of O 1s in Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 and Co/SiO2–Al2O3 are lower than the SiO2–Al2O3. The right peak around 530.3eV of the SiO2–Al2O3 is attributed to the SiO2 while the left one around 532.3eV is attributed to O in the Si–O–Si environment. It can be seen from curve b and c in Fig. 3 that the right peaks around 529.8eV and 529.7eV are respectively associated with O in the Mn–O and Co–O and the left peaks around 531.1eV and 530.7eV are both attributed to γ-Al2O3 [31]. These results indicate that the Al atoms have been replaced with the transition metal atoms, which may cause the change of the binding energies. The Mn 2p XPS core peaks of Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 and Co 2p XPS core peaks of Co/SiO2–Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 4 . It shows that the binding energies of Mn and Co in Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 and Co/SiO2–Al2O3 are higher than the standard binding energies of elemental Mn (638.6eV) and Co (777.8eV) [31]. The binding energies in Fig. 4(a) around 640.8–642.3eV are attributed to MnO and Mn3O4 [32,33]. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the binding energy around 780.1eV is assigned to Co3O4 while the others are attributed to the shake-up satellite peaks [30]. The NH3–TPD spectra are shown in Fig. 5 . The peaks at 220°C for all the samples are due to the weakly bonded ammonia adsorbed on weak Lewis sites. The peaks at 385°C and 500°C were detected in SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts, which are attributed to desorption of ammonia from the Brønsted acid sites and the later pyridine FT-IR spectra also confirm it. It suggests that stronger acid sites appear as the metals are introduced into SiO2–Al2O3. These results are consistent with the report that the Brønsted acid sites are introduced when Al3+ is isomorphously replaced by lower valence states of transition metal atoms such as divalent cations Mn2+ and Co2+ [34]. According to the above XRD and XPS patterns, Mn3O4 and MnO exist in the framework of Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 catalyst while only Co3O4 exists in Co/SiO2–Al2O3 catalyst. It may be the reason of higher Brønsted acid content in Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 catalyst. The FT-IR spectra of SiO2–Al2O3 and its supported transition metal catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . The region 3487cm−1 and 1652cm−1 are attributed to O–H bond stretching and bending vibrations of water. The adsorption peak around 2925cm−1 in trace b, c and d is the characteristic peak of the asymmetric CH2 bonds. The peaks around 798cm−1 and 466cm−1 are attributed to the typical symmetric stretching and bending vibrations of Si–O–Si of the mesoporous silica network [35]. All the Al–O and Si–O related vibrations appear only in the region of 1200–400cm−1. The peak in the region of 715cm−1 is due to ν Al–O of AlO4 polyhedron. And the peak in the region of 615cm−1 is due to ν Al–O of AlO6 [36]. The peaks in the region of 553cm−1 (trace b), 559cm−1 (trace c) and 584cm−1 (trace d) may due to the introduction of the metals. Moreover, the vibration bands of Co–Mn/SiO2–Al2O3, Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 and Co/SiO2–Al2O3 are shifted to low wavenumbers with respect to the support SiO2–Al2O3. The reason may be that the Co–O and Mn–O bonds are longer than the Al–O bond [37], which leads to the red shift of the relative characteristic peaks. And it also confirms that the metals are substituted into the framework of mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3. The pyridine FT-IR spectra of Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 7 . The IR band at 1450cm−1 is the adsorption of pyridine on Lewis acidic centers, the band at 1490cm−1 is the interaction with both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, and the bands at 1540cm−1 and 1614cm−1 are adsorption of pyridine on Brønsted acid centers. The results of pyridine FT-IR spectra indicate that the catalysts possess both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites when metals are introduced. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm and the pore size distribution of the samples are shown in Fig. 8 . The SiO2–Al2O3 and its supported transition metal catalysts show an adsorption isotherm of type IV according to the IUPAC classification and have a H4 hysteresis loop. The volume adsorbed for nitrogen steeply increases at a relative pressure (p/p 0) of approximately 0.40–0.75, representing capillary condensation of nitrogen within the uniform mesoporous structure. The mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 and its supported transition metal catalysts have a pore size distribution centered at 4.3nm. The BET surface area, pore size and pore volume of SiO2–Al2O3 and its supported transition metal catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . The BET surface areas and the pore volumes decrease when the metals are introduced. It can be seen from Table 2 that the catalyst with middle Si/Al molar ratio gives the largest surface area and pore volume. Fig. 9 illustrates the TG/DSC curves of the mesoporous SiO2–Al2O3 and its supported transition metal catalysts. As can be seen from Fig. 9(a), the first weight loss is attributed to the water desorption and the second loss from 143 to 524°C is due to the template desorption. DSC peaks near 64.5°C and 460°C are observed during these two weight losses. The weight loss of the SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts due to water desorption is similar to the SiO2–Al2O3. However, the template desorption includes two steps and have more than two thermopositive peaks on DSC curves. The different weight loss phenomenon of the mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts indicates that there are stronger interactions between the framework and the template which make the template molecules strongly bonded in it. 3.2 Catalytic tests The representative results for the nitrosation of cyclohexane over the different catalysts are summarized in Table 3 . The results indicate that the conversion of cyclohexane is very limited and it is mainly converted to benzene sulfonic acid with very low selectivity to ɛ-caprolactam in the absence of catalyst. While the ɛ-caprolactam could be efficiently obtained from cyclohexane and nitrosyl sulfuric acid over these catalysts, which indicates that the catalysts play an important role in promoting the conversion of cyclohexane and the formation of ɛ-caprolactam. From these results we can see that the catalytic activity increases with the increment of the BET surface area. The mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 with the largest surface area gives the largest conversion of 9.40%. Although the conversion decreases when the metals are introduced, the selectivity to ɛ-caprolactam increases. The SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts provide stronger Brønsted acid sites when manganese and cobalt oxides formed, which may be instrumental to the rearrangement of nitroso cyclohexane to cyclohexanone oxime and cyclohexanone oxime to ɛ-caprolactam (see Scheme 1 ). Among these SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts, the Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 with more Brønsted acid sites and larger surface area gives the best result of conversion of 7.34% and ɛ-caprolactam selectivity of 50.59%. It has been found that benzene sulfonic acid, cyclohexylnitrite and nitroso cyclohexene were formed as by-products during the cyclohexane nitrosation catalyzed by VPO catalyst [22]. On the basis of the results of liquid chromatograph–mass spectrometer and gas chromatograph–mass spectrometer, it can be found that besides these by-products, benzene disulfonic acid, cyclohexenylnitrite and the condensate of the ɛ-caprolactam are also detected during the cyclohexane nitrosation process. A possible mechanism for the liquid phase nitrosation of cyclohexane is proposed in Scheme 1. Under the catalysis, the nitrosyl sulfuric acid could decompose to ON and HO3SO free radicals via the N–O bond cleavage and it also could decompose to ONO and HO3S free radicals via the S–O bond cleavage. The results of quantum-mechanical calculation show that the bond length of N–O (1.654Å) is longer than the S–O (1.583Å) in nitrosyl sulfuric acid and the bond cleavage of N–O is easier than the S–O. The energy and bond energy of various substances are shown in Table 4 . In the N–O bond cleavage path, the formed HO3SO free radical reacts with cyclohexane forming sulfuric acid and cyclohexyl free radical. Then the obtained cyclohexyl free radical reacts with nitroso radical (ON) giving nitroso cyclohexane, which is the key intermediate to form cyclohexanone oxime and the condensate of ɛ-caprolactam which is detected by the liquid chromatograph–mass spectrometer. And a small quantity of nitroso cyclohexane is dehydrogenated to nitroso cyclohexene by-product. Then, the obtained cyclohexanone oxime can be transformed to ɛ-caprolactam through Beckmann rearrangement and the condensate of ɛ-caprolactam can be hydrolyzed to ɛ-caprolactam [38]. In the S–O bond cleavage path, the formed HO3S free radical reacts with cyclohexane giving sulfurous acid and cyclohexyl free radical. Then the obtained cyclohexyl radical either reacts with ONO free radical forming cyclohexylnitrite, or reacts with fuming sulfuric acid giving cyclohexane sulfonic acid. After that, a small quantity of cyclohexylnitrite could be dehydrogenated to cyclohexenylnitrite and the obtained cyclohexane sulfonic acid is easily dehydrogenated to benzene sulfonic acid. Furthermore, part of benzene sulfonic acid reacts with SO3 forming benzene disulfonic acid. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis method and its supported Co or Mn catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. These prepared materials were characterized by XRD, XPS, NH3–TPD, BET, FT-IR and TG–DSC. The XRD and XPS patterns detect the characteristic peaks belong to MnCo2O4, Mn3O4, MnO and Co3O4. FT-IR and TG–DSC results also indicate that the metals are substituted into the framework of SiO2–Al2O3. BET surface areas and the pore volumes decrease when the metals are introduced into the SiO2–Al2O3. TPD and pyridine FT-IR results show that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites exist on these SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts. Brønsted acid sites appear when manganese and cobalt oxides formed due to the introduction of the transition metals, it may be the reason of the increasement of selectivity to ɛ-caprolactam. The results show that both the mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 and its supported transition metal catalysts can catalyze cyclohexane nitrosation for one-step synthesis of ɛ-caprolactam in the presence of fuming sulfuric acid and the catalysts play an important role in promoting the conversion of cyclohexane and the formation of ɛ-caprolactam. Among these SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts, the Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 with stronger acidity and relatively larger BET surface area gives the best result of conversion of 7.34% and ɛ-caprolactam selectivity of 50.59%. A possible mechanism for liquid phase nitrosation of cyclohexane was proposed. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous crystalline SiO2–Al2O3 was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis method and its supported Co or Mn catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. These prepared materials were characterized by XRD, XPS, NH3–TPD, BET, FT-IR and TG–DSC. It reveals that the metals are substituted into the framework as the form of MnCo2O4, Mn3O4, MnO, Co3O4 and stronger acid sites appear. Furthermore, Pyridine FT-IR spectra and NH3–TPD results indicate that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites exist on these SiO2–Al2O3 supported transition metal catalysts and Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 exhibits higher Brønsted acid content. BET results show that SiO2–Al2O3 with middle Si/Al molar ratio has larger surface area and pore volume. The surface area and pore volume of SiO2–Al2O3 decrease after the introduction of the transition metals. The catalytic properties in the cyclohexane nitrosation to ɛ-caprolactam were performed and Mn/SiO2–Al2O3 exhibits better activity and selectivity to the ɛ-caprolactam.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of mesoporous SiO2–Al2O3 supported Co or Mn catalysts and their catalytic properties in cyclohexane nitrosation to ɛ-caprolactam
